page.title: 06Miners Strike (Miners Wives)
page.content: For years the miners wives have been contented to be homemakers and let their menfolk take the lead in politics. The 1984-85 miners strike changed all that. The women, who mostly supported their husbands in their strike, were forced out of their homes to organise food parcels and lunch clubs for the miners families. They quickly learned how to organise themselves into an extremely well run co-operative. They organised meals, clothes, collections for money and food. As the strike progressed many husbands found they were taking second place to to the "committee" and some did not like it. Undeterred the women expanded their interests by forming a "committee" for the whole of Fife. For many of the women it was their first active role outside their families.
